column102: Well, the idea that there is equality is not true, specifically when it comes to a career.  At all levels of my career there were obstacles for me as a women in science. When I was studying there was still the prejudice about a women studying in computer science, that they might not be capable, that a computer scientist cannot be pretty and clever, ... In my studies it was clearly mentioned by male students that they would never accept a women as a boss (1989). This might have changed but is was the mindset of that time. In all levels of my career I was the only women. When I had success it was then sometimes mentioned that it was because I was a women. Womens' topics and talking about equality was for decades something that women - such as me - were fighting for - it took until around 2020 when more men were stepping in and understanding equality as a responsibility for all genders. I have lost 20% of my intellectual potential and time because I was a women, because I had to show more to get the same positions, because I had to spend time in committee meetings when others made their careers, because I was not in the right boys networks, ... That is a loss not only for me but also a loss for a society as this did not happen to me but to many women.
column107: Never give up, connect in women networks, reveal the inequality in all places and situations I see it, mentor young women, give women a voice, make institutions change and implement gender equality plans. ... keep moving forward.
column108: For too many years I felt it was alway me mentioning to respect and be aware of inequality. For a decade I mentioned it in so many meeting, that it is not only Mitarbeiter but also Mitarbeiterin, that it is not man month but person months and so on.  Women were responsible for gender quality. Women who were acting to make change got a negative image as "Emanze" (feminist). The universities took and my institute took a long time to finally implement better rules for gender quality. Only in 2021 we see some gender equality plan  now on the university level, on the level of European Projects and so on. But is was a very long and low process.

column73: Wheras in the US the option after my studies were clear with a career path: assistant professor - tenure - associate professor, this doesn't exist the same way in Germany. Most horrible is the hierarchy at German universities and that the experience of women women somehow doesn't count. In Germany workshops at conferences are held and five men discuss on stage the "problems of women" in science, how can that be? I am working with six young women in my team who are constantly confronted with the issue of when is the right time for motherhood? To be honest there is actually no right time for motherhood when persuing a career in science. And the data speaks for itself, men and women are following a similar path until the end of their doctorate and then men proceed onto becoming professors and women don't know how to combine motherhood and a career in science. Of all professorships in Germany only 29 percent are held by women that speaks for itself. I am coordinating a research cluster with a total of 50 projects (yes no tipo you can imagine my workload) and not even a quarter of the PIs are women. In contrast to that women at the Master or doctoral candidate level outnumber men. The director of the instute I am working at likes to devide Post-Doc positions. It means that he hires two Post-Docs at 50 percent but expects that both will work 80 to 100 percent and that's not possible with children. All of the young women in my team have decided to leave science after the project ends next year because of the frustrations and not being able to find a permanent position. As long as the dependence in science stays that way nothing will change for the better.

It would be good to create future surveys a little more unbiased. A lot of the questions already seem to assume certain types of problems or have probably unintended meanings. One example is:

"Have you ever faced men are given priority over female researcher"

Some researchers will always be given priority over others and given a large enough and mixed sample, this will very likely always have to be answered with "yes". On the other hand, what I suspect is meant (but did not ask) is: "Have you ever faced men are given priority over female researchers at least partially because of their gender?"
But even with that question I am not sure what value results of that question would have. If it is to state the known (?) fact that given priority because of gender happens a lot, then the other side would still be missing from the picture: I would guess that men would answer the corresponding question for women given priority over men almost all with 'yes', too.

column167:
Another thing: My career goal (becoming a professor) was not taken seriously by my doctoral supervisor (a professor with kids) and group leader (gay without kids) because both assumed and told me (!) that I would change my mind about this anyways and rather have kids. I have never talked about kids with them. They uttered these things the first time at the beginning of my PhD aged 23, with them continuing to say so until I defended aged 27 (spoiler alter I did not change my perspective on wanting to become a professor or not wanting to have kids, which should be none of their business anyway). 

Tips that helped me:
Look for male allies. Male researchers advocating for me or just seeing what was going on made a huge difference for me. It's so great when someone else in the room speaks up for you and tells others off (for example, in one case, highlighting that the proposed idea would mean dividing something along the gender line had, I think way more power coming from a senior male scientist than from me). Also, men educating other men seem to be way more fruitful.

Join forces with other women. Hearing others face similar issues made me realize that paternalism and misogyny were at work, not me being wrong.

Educate men. I hate doing this myself, but I would really love if men would just be educated on all the issues women face (including periods) so that they are enabled to reflect on their behaviour or the behaviour of others around them.

Some men have issues talking to women. That is not your problem but theirs. (This is something I am trying to remind myself of constantly)

Leave places where misogyny is present if you can. Being in an environment where I feel much more valued and seen, and I don't have to put up with older men telling me to have kids or dress more feminine really made a difference in my mental health, general well-being and productivity.
